facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 103 and 105 of 1956 were brought on certificates granted by the Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 103 105 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2546 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeals raise common questions of law and were heard together.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals, brought on certificates granted by the High Court of Bombay, raise companymon questions of law and for that reason, have been heard together. This judgment will govern them both.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1956, main appellant is Barsi Light Railway Company Limited, Kurduwadi.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1956 the main appellant is the Barsi Light Railway Company Limited, Kurduwadi, within the State of Bombay  hereinafter called the Railway Company .

facts.text: Agreement dated August 1, 1895, between Secretary of State for India in Council and Railway Company for constructing, maintaining and working light railway between Barsi Town and Barsi Road Station.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated August 1, 1895, between the Secretary of State for India in Council and the Railway Company, the latter companystructed, maintained and worked a light railway between Barsi Town and Barsi Road Station on the railway system, known then as the Great Indian Peninsular Railway.

facts.text: Notice given on December 19, 1952, by Director of Railway Board on behalf of President of India to purchase and take over Railway Company undertaking as from January 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On December 19, 1952, a numberice was given to the Railway Company, for and on behalf of the President of India, by the Director of the Railway Board to the effect that the undertaking of the Railway Company would be purchased and taken over as from January 1, 1954.

facts.text: Railway Company served notice on November 11, 1953, to workmen terminating services from afternoon of December 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On November 11, 1953, the Railway Company served a numberice on its workmen intimating that as a result of the Government of Indias decision to terminate the companytract of the Railway Company and take over the railway from January 1, 1954, the services of all the workmen of the Railway Company would be terminated with effect from the afternoon of December 31, 1953.

facts.text: Railway Board intimated terms and conditions on December 15, 1953, for staff taken over by Government.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1953, the Railway Board intimated the terms and companyditions on which the staff of the Railway Company would be taken over and employed by Government.

facts.text: Undertaking taken over on January 1, 1954; about 77% staff re-employed on same scales of pay, 23% on lower scales, 24 declined service.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the statement of respondents 4 and 5 that when the undertaking was actually taken over on January 1, 1954, about 77 per cent. of the staff of the Railway Company were re-employed on the same scales of pay, about 23 per cent. were re-employed on somewhat lower scales of pay though the pay which they actually drew at the time of re-employment was number affected only about 24 of the former employees of the Railway Company declined service under the Government.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed sixty-one applications under s. 15 of Payment of Wages Act, 1936, for retrenchment compensation under cl. (b) of s. 25F of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after, respondent No. I filed some sixty-one applications on behalf of the erstwhile workmen of the Railway Company under s. 15 of the Payment of Wages Act, 1936, for payment of retrenchment companypensation to the said workmen under cl.  b  of a. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Applications made to Civil Judge Junior Division Madha, who found no jurisdiction but entitled to compensation and retrenched.

anchor.surface_text: The applications were made to respondent No. 3, Civil Judge  Junior Division  Madha, who was the relevant authority under the Payment of Wages Act, 1936. These applications were companytested by -the present appellants and several issues were framed. ... The Civil Judge of Madha found against the workmen on issue No. I but in their favour on the other two issues.

facts.text: Bombay High Court judgment and order dated January 24, 1955, in Special Civil Application No. 2546 of 1954 held workmen entitled to compensation under s. 25F(b).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2546 of 1954.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1956, main appellant is Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd., Baroda, running woollen mill with 450 workmen and 20 clerks.

anchor.surface_text: The main appellant is Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd., Baroda, and the principal respondent is the District Labour Officer and Inspector under the Payment of Wages Act, 1936, at Baroda. The appellant Company was running a woollen mill at Baroda for several years and had in its employ at the relevant time 450 workmen and 20 clerks.

facts.text: Dinesh Mills notice on or about October 31, 1953, declaring intention to close down entire mills from December 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On or about October 31, 1953, the appellant put up a numberice declaring its intention to close down the entire mills from December 1, 1953.

facts.text: Notice withdrawn November 19, 1953, new notice to close second shift from December 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19,1953, this numberice was withdrawn and another numberice was put up declaring the intention of the appellant to close down the second shift with effect from December 20, 1953.

facts.text: Third notice: second shift closed December 20, 1953, first shift from January 8, 1954; clerks terminated January 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: A third numberice was put up saying that the second shift would be closed on December 20, 1953, as numberified earlier, and the first shift would be closed as from January 8, 1954. A similar numberice was put up on the same date terminating the services of the clerks with effect from January 19,1954.

facts.text: Closure of Dinesh Mills business bona fide due to heavy losses; services of all 450 workmen and 20 clerks terminated.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disput- ed that though the steps in the process of closure of the business of the appellant Company were staggered,. the process was really one, and as a result of the closure the services of all 450 workmen and 20 clerks were terminated. The appellant Company claimed that the closure of its business was bona fide, being due to heavy losses sustained by the Company.

facts.text: Application by principal respondent on April 27, 1954, to authority under Payment of Wages Act for retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On April 27, 1954, the principal respondent made an application to the relevant authority  respondent No. 3  under the Payment of Wages Act, 1936, claiming retrenchment companypensation for the workmen of the appellant under el.  b  of s. 25F of the Act.

facts.text: Authority under Payment of Wages Act decided against workmen on jurisdiction and maintainability.

anchor.surface_text: The authority under the Payment of Wages Act decided against the erstwhile workmen on all the important issues.

facts.text: Bombay High Court decision dated July 25, 1955, set aside lower order and directed disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1956 is from the aforesaid decision of the High Court dated July 25, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds termination of services on bona fide closure or takeover not retrenchment under s. 2(oo) and s. 25F.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold, companytrary to the view expressed by the Bombay High Court, that retrenchment as defined in s. 2  oo  and as used in s. 25F has numberwider meaning than the ordinary, accepted companynotation of the word it means the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and. it has numberapplication where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on a real and bona fide closure of business as in the case of Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd. or where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on the business or undertaking being taken over by another employer in circumstances like those of the Railway Company.

facts.text: Appeals allowed, High Court decisions set aside; appellants not liable for compensation under s. 25F.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are number liable to pay any companypensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were number retrenched within the meaning of that expression in that section.

holdings.text: retrenchment as defined in s. 2(oo) and as used in s. 25F has no wider meaning than the ordinary, accepted connotation of the word; it means the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and it has no application where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on a real and bona fide closure of business as in the case of Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd. or where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on the business or undertaking being taken over by another employer in circumstances like those of the Railway Company.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold, contrary to the view expressed by the Bombay High Court, that retrenchment as defined in s. 2(oo) and as used in s. 25F has no wider meaning than the ordinary, accepted connotation of the word it means the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and. it has no application where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on a real and bona fide closure of business as in the case of Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd. or where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on the business or undertaking being taken over by another employer in circumstances like those of the Railway Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary connotation of retrenchment as discharge of surplus in continuing business fulfills all elements of s.2(oo) definition; scheme of Ch.VA and Act assumes existing industry; ss.25G/25H inapplicable to closed business; prior tribunal awards were equitable, not definitional.

holdings.text: the appellants in the two appeals are not liable to pay any compensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were not retrenched within the meaning of that expression in that section.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are not liable to pay any compensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were not retrenched within the meaning of that expression in that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of narrow interpretation of retrenchment to facts of bona fide closure (Dinesh Mills) and takeover termination (Railway); reverses High Court.

holdings.text: s. 25FF is partial supersession of judicial decisions assuming wide retrenchment meaning, not parliamentary exposition of pre-existing law in s.2(oo) and s.25F.

anchor.surface_text: the legislature could not declare the decisions to be incorrect, but could partially supersede their effect by an amendment of the law. These were the circumstances in which s. 25FF was enacted. We agree with learned counsel for the appellants that the aim or object of the enactment was to supersede partially the effect of the aforesaid judicial decisions, at least with regard to the urgent matter of change of ownership or management of a business undertaking which is of quite frequent occurrence, rather than parliamentary exposition of the pre-existing law

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25FF enacted post-High Court decisions to mitigate deadlock from wide retrenchment including transfer/closure; Schedules in 1956 Amendment Act distinguish retrenchment from closure; history shows supersession, not exposition.

holdings.text: prior to 1953 amendment, retrenchment had no special meaning including bona fide closure; tribunal awards were equitable relief varying by case, not uniform definition.

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment means discharge of surplus workmen in an existing or continuing business it had acquired no special meaning so as to include discharge of workmen on bona fide closure of business though a number of Labour Appellate Tribunals awarded compensation to workmen on closure of business as an equitable relief for a variety of reasons. It is reasonable to assume that in enacting s. 25F, the legislature standardised the payment of compensation to workmen retrenched in the normal or ordinary sense in an existing or Continuing industry

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined tribunal decisions (e.g., Hyderabad Vegetable, Kandan Textiles); awards based on unemployment, no social security, company finances as equity, not definitional; s.25F standardizes ordinary retrenchment compensation.

holdings.text: s.25F has no application to a closed or dead industry.

anchor.surface_text: On our construction, s. 25F has no application to a closed or dead industry and the constitutional arguments based on a different construction need not be considered in these appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow construction of retrenchment obviates constitutional challenge under Art.19(1)(g) re right to close business; no need to decide validity.

outcome.relief_summary: The two appeals are allowed. The decisions of the Bombay High Court are set aside. Appellants held not liable to pay retrenchment compensation under s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act to erstwhile workmen as there was no retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold, contrary to the view expressed by the Bombay High Court, that retrenchment as defined in s. 2(oo) and as used in s. 25F has no wider meaning than the ordinary, accepted connotation of the word it means the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and. it has no application where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on a real and bona fide closure of business as in the case of Shri Dinesh Mills Ltd. or where the services of all workmen have been terminated by the employer on the business or undertaking being taken over by another employer in circumstances like those of the Railway Company.

edges.explanation: holding on s.2(oo) definition addresses issue of ordinary notion vs definition

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are number liable to pay any companypensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were

In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are not liable to pay any compensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were not retrenched within the meaning of that expression in that section.

anchor.surface_text: the legislature could not declare the decisions to be incorrect, but could partially supersede their effect by an amendment of the law. These were the circumstances in which s. 25FF was enacted. We agree with learned counsel for the appellants that the aim or object of the enactment was to supersede partially the effect of the aforesaid judicial decisions, at least with regard to the urgent matter of change of ownership or management of a business undertaking which is of quite frequent occurrence, rather than parliamentary exposition of the pre-existing law

In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are number liable to pay any companypensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were

edges.explanation: Holding rejects exposition for s.25FF despite precedent treating subsequent legislation as exposition.

The holding on pre-1953 lack of uniform definition of retrenchment ('prior to 1953 amendment, retrenchment had no special meaning including bona fide closure; tribunal awards were equitable relief varying by case, not uniform definition') supports applying harmonious construction to ensure the new definition fits the Act's scheme assuming existing industry.
The holding on the pre-1953 absence of a uniform definition of retrenchment grounds the context and purpose of Chapter VA, which introduced provisions for lay-off and retrenchment.
pre-1953 no meaning including closure supports interpretive exclusion in c2
historical no special inclusion of closure supports h1 ordinary connotation

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment means discharge of surplus workmen in an existing or continuing business it had acquired no special meaning so as to include discharge of workmen on bona fide closure of business though a number of Labour Appellate Tribunals awarded compensation to workmen on closure of business as an equitable relief for a variety of reasons. It is reasonable to assume that in enacting s. 25F, the legislature standardised the payment of compensation to workmen retrenched in the normal or ordinary sense in an existing or Continuing industry

In the result, we must allow the two appeals and set aside the decisions of the High Court of Bombay in the two cases. We hold that the appellants in the two appeals are number liable to pay any companypensation under s. 25F of the Act to their erstwhile workmen who were
